{{More citations needed|date=April 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Chance | image = | caption = | image_size = | alias = | origin = [[Texas]], U.S. | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | years_active = 1985–1988 | label = [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville]] | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = | past_members = [[Jeff Chance|Jeff Barosh]]
Mick Barosh
John Buckley
Jon Mulligan
Billy Hafer }} '''Chance''' was an American [[country music]] group composed of Jeff Barosh (vocals, fiddle, steel guitar, sax, guitar), Mick Barosh (drums), John Buckley (guitar), Jon Mulligan (keyboards), and Billy Hafer (bass). The group recorded one album for [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville]] in 1985 which included the Top 40 singles "To Be Lovers" and "She Told Me Yes." Previously known in the south Texas area as "Texas Pride", they changed their name to "Chance" after securing a record deal and gaining national recognition in the mid-1980s. Keyboard player Jon Mulligan was killed by a drunk driver in 1987 on the way home from one of the group's local Texas concerts. Keyboardist Clay Hemphill filled the duty on the keys from 1987 to 1993 during the transition years from "Chance" to "Jeff Chance". Bill Hafer retired in 1993 to pursue his custom flight case business, "Hafer Case". Bruce Repka joined the band in 1993 on keyboards & steel. Fred Rice (bass) came aboard but left a year later. Darrell Jozwiak filled the role of bass guitarist from 1994 until the band played their last gig together in October 1995. Lead singer Jeff Barosh launched a solo career in the late 1980s - early 1990s as [[Jeff Chance]] and charted three singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart.[https://secure4.worldsites.net/countrymusicnews-ca/news.ihtml?step=2&article_id=1515 CD Review - Jeff Chance - Back Again] {{webarchive |url=https://archive.today/20110721214705/https://secure4.worldsites.net/countrymusicnews-ca/news.ihtml?step=2&article_id=1515 |date=July 21, 2011 }} [[Shania Twain]] sang background vocals on his 1992 album ''Walk Softly On The Bridges''. Barosh died on December 12, 2008, at the age of 53.{{Cite web|url=http://obits.victoriaadvocate.com/obituaries/victoriaadvocate/obituary.aspx|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20120713111615/http://obits.victoriaadvocate.com/obituaries/victoriaadvocate/obituary.aspx?page=notice&pid=121335013|url-status=dead|title=Jeffery Barosh Sr. Obituary: View Jeffery Barosh's Obituary by Victoria Advocate|website=Archive.today|archivedate=2012-07-13|access-date=2020-04-19}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:14em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:20em;"| Album details ! colspan="1"| Peak positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="60"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]] |- ! scope="row"| ''Chance'' | * Release date: January 1986 * Label: Mercury Records | 65 |- |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable" !
